<h2>Resource and energy systems</h2>
<p>During the Era of Markets, global consumption of increasingly abundant fossil fuels continued to rise, but this broader access to energy resources came with rising awareness of the damage being done to the climate. Many countries have committed to striving to achieve net-zero carbon emissions, and attention has shifted from investment in fossil fuels to investment in replacing them. However, in the new era, countries may well need to grapple with a paradox: the current pace of investment in renewable energy is too slow to meet ambitions for carbon abatement, but investment in fossil fuels may be too low to make up the shortfall in energy supply. By 2019, 72 percent of net new annual electricity-generating capacity globally came from renewables.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d0133d00-0fb8-47bd-a934-4c8e2a6ef008"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">39</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d0133d00-0fb8-47bd-a934-4c8e2a6ef008" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Renewable totals include hydropower, wind, solar, bioenergy, and geothermal. They do not include nuclear power. See <em>Renewable capacity highlights</em>, International Renewable Energy Agency, March 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> However, 84 percent of the global gigajoules consumed still came from fossil energy sourcesa figure that has been broadly stable for 30 years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cde30346-d2df-4311-8c09-07b7ffb25e74"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">40</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cde30346-d2df-4311-8c09-07b7ffb25e74" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">BP, <em>Statistical review of world energy</em>, 71st edition, 2022. Figures represent primary energy consumption and use the substitution method to adjust for inefficiencies in fossil fuel use, to improve comparability to renewable energy sources. Note that these figures do not include traditional biomass in total global energy use.</span></span></span></a></span> Global investment in energy supply had stagnated; in 2022, global spending on energy supply infrastructure was well below the 2014 peak. Achieving net zero will require a significant ramp-up in global energy investment, but the war in Ukraine and tightening global financial conditions could challenge the velocity of the transition.</p>
<h4>How will Latin America power itself and reduce its greenhouse-gas emissions?</h4>
<p>Latin America faces three idiosyncrasies that may shape its path to decarbonization. First, many economies in the region rely on fossil fuels for income and foreign exchange.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fe8540e5-cf1f-4539-8a04-97c5f4cca008"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">41</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fe8540e5-cf1f-4539-8a04-97c5f4cca008" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Climate change challenges in Latin America and the Caribbean, in <em>Regional economic outlook: Western Hemisphere</em>, IMF, October 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> At the same time, the region enjoys some of the best conditions globally for renewable power generation, including hydro, wind, and solar power; the Andes have the highest photovoltaic power potential of any region in the world.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e6136b96-89e9-44e6-bf73-9691250f4e08"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">42</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e6136b96-89e9-44e6-bf73-9691250f4e08" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Global photovoltaic power potential by country</em>, World Bank, June 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> In the near term, higher energy commodity prices may encourage fossil fuel exports and add momentum for the domestic shift to renewables. Between 2018 and 2022, Latin Americas solar power capacity grew by around 35 percent every year. This was well over double the global average growth rate, and the fastest of any world region.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a883020e-229c-43f3-85a3-a66065b1ff30"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">43</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a883020e-229c-43f3-85a3-a66065b1ff30" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">IRENA, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Second, even though electricity production is relatively decarbonized by global standards, electrifying and decarbonizing energy as a whole is still a formidable task that will require significant shifts and investment. About 60 percent of electricity in Latin America is from renewable sourcestwice the global average.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="df359e2e-f654-4a98-a780-0fca1a268bfc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">44</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="df359e2e-f654-4a98-a780-0fca1a268bfc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Yearly electricity data, Ember, March 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> But only about 20 percent of final energy use in Latin America is from electricity, a figure similar to the global average.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1f4c0e72-c187-4e8a-9a14-169bf1ab1c6b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">45</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1f4c0e72-c187-4e8a-9a14-169bf1ab1c6b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">World Energy Balances, International Energy Agency, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Decarbonization of sectors such as transportation and industry could be accelerated by making further use of the regions potential for solar, wind, biomethane, and biofuels as well as existing hydroelectric power.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="eea2b4c6-e352-4ec9-835a-3e302cebb979"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">46</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="eea2b4c6-e352-4ec9-835a-3e302cebb979" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-energy-transition-a-region-by-region-agenda-for-near-term-action">The energy transition: A region-by-region agenda for near-term action</a></em>, McKinsey & Company, December 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Latin America could also become a significant low-cost producer of hydrogen, not only supporting domestic decarbonization but also potentially supplying a growing global market.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ce1c0f34-7130-4bba-af5e-c423f4c09af6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">47</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ce1c0f34-7130-4bba-af5e-c423f4c09af6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">International Energy Agency, <em>Hydrogen in Latin America</em>, August 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Third, Latin America will need to address land-use emissions more than most other regions. Energy accounts for only 43 percent of greenhouse-gas emissions in Latin America, versus a global average of about 74 percent. Agriculture, land-use change, and forestry contribute 45 percent of its emissions, versus a global average of about 14 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cb240eca-432b-4353-af88-571f4794de96"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">48</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cb240eca-432b-4353-af88-571f4794de96" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Climate change challenges in Latin America and the Caribbean, in <em>Regional economic outlook: Western Hemisphere</em>, IMF, October 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Decarbonization will create domestic trade-offs. McKinsey research found that the region would have to allocate just under 10 percent of its GDP on physical assets to supporting the net-zero transition, about two percentage points above the world average.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0c4a0e21-67b1-408a-b076-834aa065d4e1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">49</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0c4a0e21-67b1-408a-b076-834aa065d4e1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-net-zero-transition-what-it-would-cost-what-it-could-bring">The net-zero transition: What it would cost, what it could bring</a>, McKinsey Global Institute, January 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Delivering on domestic decarbonization will require overcoming challenges such as securing financing and unlocking permitting and approvals, and addressing talent and infrastructure gaps.</p>
<h4>Can Latin America be an engine of the global net-zero transition?</h4>
<p> Many critical resources needed for the net-zero transition are abundant in the region (Exhibit 5). Latin America holds about half of the worlds lithium, 36 percent of its copper, and 16 percent of its nickel. Brazil is estimated to have one of the largest reserves of rare earths outside China.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7bbf2f7e-edee-4cb7-b2e8-80178bd01588"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">50</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7bbf2f7e-edee-4cb7-b2e8-80178bd01588" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Mineral commodity summaries</em>, US Geological Survey, January 2023. Stated proportions are of world reserves.</span></span></span></a></span> Moreover, Latin America also contains about 50 percent of the worlds biodiversity and 23 percent of its forestskey elements of global climate stability and broader sustainability, and a crucial complement to the energy transition.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a28a9bf-3418-47dd-9f57-0431dc7df365"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">51</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a28a9bf-3418-47dd-9f57-0431dc7df365" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>The outlook for agriculture and rural development in the Americas: A perspective on Latin America and the Caribbean</em>, ECLAC, FAO, and IICA, 2019. This publication does not specify the metric of biodiversity used.</span></span></span></a></span> The region therefore has a unique opportunity to support global decarbonization, from renewable value chains to forest carbon sequestration. However, there are potential tensions between the needs of local communities and the global requirements of the transition. The debate over lithium mining in Chile is an example.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d2b09b7c-0f69-401b-a602-4b3aea95d86a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">52</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d2b09b7c-0f69-401b-a602-4b3aea95d86a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">John Bartlett, Mining of lithium, key to the climate fight, faces new scrutiny in Chile, <em>New York Times</em>, January 6, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Similarly, reducing deforestation and practicing afforestation would need to be carefully managed in order to ensure that forest-border communities benefit.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ae8f56c1-50df-452f-8b76-ca610bd41f0b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">53</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ae8f56c1-50df-452f-8b76-ca610bd41f0b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-net-zero-transition-what-it-would-cost-what-it-could-bring">The net-zero transition: What it would cost, what it could bring</a>, McKinsey Global Institute, January 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20global%20institute/our%20research/what%20could%20a%20new%20era%20mean%20for%20latin%20america/svgz-latam-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20global%20institute/our%20research/what%20could%20a%20new%20era%20mean%20for%20latin%20america/svgz-latam-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>Capitalization</h2>
<p>As its name suggests, the Era of Markets saw the rise of market economies around the world. Hypergrowth in Chinaat close to 10 percent annually throughout the eraas well as growth in India and some Southeast Asian economies propelled a shift in global GDP growth from high-income to low- and middle-income economies. In advanced economies, the productivity boom of the late 1990s started tapering off in the mid-2000s.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a719146a-17a8-4235-aa0e-cd5811cb0671"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">54</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a719146a-17a8-4235-aa0e-cd5811cb0671" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">See, for example, <em>The productivity puzzle</em>, McKinsey Global Institute, March 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> But the Era of Markets also witnessed a record rise in household, nonfinancial corporate, and government debt. Total debt in advanced economies is at its highest level since the end of World War II.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c5a7a149-9016-4974-a80c-439eb7c87c89"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">55</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c5a7a149-9016-4974-a80c-439eb7c87c89" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In G-20 countries, the ratio of total debt to GDP is over 300 percent. From 2000 to 2021, the world created $2 in new debt for each $1 in net new investment. Asset prices soared, supporting an accumulation of paper wealth. Net worth grew by 170 percentage points relative to GDP, yet three-quarters of wealth growth stemmed from asset price inflation rather than saving and investing. See <em><a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/global-balance-sheet-2022-enter-volatility">Global balance sheet 2022: Enter volatility</a></em>, McKinsey Global Institute, December 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In a new era, whose start is marked by a spike in inflation and rising interest rates, the global balance sheet seems exposed. Accelerating productivity growth will be badly needed.</p>
<h4>How will the region navigate global economic headwinds?</h4>
<p>The region appears to be recovering from the pandemic-induced shock. Consumption, employment, and economic activity are all above prepandemic levels.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="54fa890c-8344-4b14-bfc4-9312aba8fe29"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">56</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="54fa890c-8344-4b14-bfc4-9312aba8fe29" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Regional economic outlook: Western Hemisphere</em>, IMF, October 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> But inflation remains high despite the fact that the regions central banks moved faster and more aggressively than most advanced economies in raising rates.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e626e028-f39d-46f9-b266-59d905003cbc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">57</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e626e028-f39d-46f9-b266-59d905003cbc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Michael Stott, Latin Americas inflation lessons for the G7, <em>Financial Times</em>, October 18, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Public debt jumped to over 70 percent of GDP during the pandemic, which could prove to be a drag on future growth and raise questions about debt sustainability if economic conditions were to deteriorate (Exhibit 6).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8d900746-b830-43be-8a2b-f9c32e787b01"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">58</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8d900746-b830-43be-8a2b-f9c32e787b01" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Andrew Powell and Oscar Mauricio Valencia, <em>Dealing with debt: Less risk for more growth in Latin America and the Caribbean</em>, Inter-American Development Bank, January 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Ongoing US monetary tightening could have a negative impact on Latin Americas economies. Slower global growth could remove the recent counterbalancing effect of higher commodity prices.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3c9f4e64-413e-4dce-b72c-e854785914f0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">59</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3c9f4e64-413e-4dce-b72c-e854785914f0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Background paper 1: Spillovers of US monetary tightening to Latin America, in <em>Regional economic outlook: Western Hemisphere</em>, IMF, October 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Given that Latin American governments and corporations have a high proportion of debt denominated in US dollars relative to others, the regions ability to service its debt is particularly exposed to exchange-rate risk.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="571df8c3-50d7-455c-bc61-ae6da7f7eb09"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">60</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="571df8c3-50d7-455c-bc61-ae6da7f7eb09" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ian Giraldo and Philip Turner, <em>The dollar debt of companies in Latin America: The warning signs</em>, Fondo Latinamerico de Reservas, February 2022; and Paulina Restrepo-Echavarria and Praew Grittayaphong, <em>Dollar-denominated public debt in Asia and Latin America</em>, Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, August 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> This risk is exacerbated as the US dollar continues to appreciate relative to many local currencies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0f97def2-f892-4e83-a2d8-3a80095b0bd2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">61</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0f97def2-f892-4e83-a2d8-3a80095b0bd2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nur Cristiani et al., <em>Latin America outlook 2023: Down, not out</em>, JP Morgan Private Bank, December 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 6</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20global%20institute/our%20research/what%20could%20a%20new%20era%20mean%20for%20latin%20america/svgz-latam-ex6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20global%20institute/our%20research/what%20could%20a%20new%20era%20mean%20for%20latin%20america/svgz-latam-ex6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h4>Will Latin America be able to drive productivity growth?</h4>
<p>Since the early 1980s, Latin Americas productivity growth rate has averaged only 0.4 percent each yearabout one-fifth of the average in developing economies globally.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="33321ad5-f2ae-4551-9a32-3be93d7ec42f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">62</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="33321ad5-f2ae-4551-9a32-3be93d7ec42f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Digital transition, technological change and productive development policies in LAC: Challenges and opportunities</em>, International Labour Organization, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> While comparable emerging Asian and Eastern European economies have experienced rapid real per capita economic growth, Latin America has not (Exhibit 7).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="57ac05b8-e9f4-47dd-81a6-cec06ae6e83d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">63</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="57ac05b8-e9f4-47dd-81a6-cec06ae6e83d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Bas B. Bakker et al., <em>The lack of convergence of Latin-America compared with CESEE: Is low investment to blame?</em> IMF working paper number 2020/098, June 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> There are wide-ranging reasons for this, including higher barriers to doing business as well as gaps in human, technological, and infrastructural capital.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="36e2fc4b-9602-47f5-9e3f-8964ed3429e7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">64</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="36e2fc4b-9602-47f5-9e3f-8964ed3429e7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/featured-insights/employment-and-growth/how-to-counter-three-threats-to-growth-in-latin-america">Where will Latin Americas growth come from?</a></em>, McKinsey Global Institute, April 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> The competitive dynamics of the region contribute, too. Firms are polarized into large incumbents and a long tail of small, unproductive, and often informal firms, with a missing middle of dynamic midsize companies that can challenge incumbents, innovate, and drive growth.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dba21457-1ba7-4495-be85-313561b6ecf8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">65</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dba21457-1ba7-4495-be85-313561b6ecf8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/featured-insights/americas/latin-americas-missing-middle-of-midsize-firms-and-middle-class-spending-power">Latin Americas missing middle: Rebooting inclusive growth</a></em>, McKinsey Global Institute, May 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> In particular, midsize firms face challenges accessing capital to enable growth; about 30 percent of them report finance as a major constraint.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9c9c978e-e53c-46ab-9cd3-7f7274005a2d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">66</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9c9c978e-e53c-46ab-9cd3-7f7274005a2d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Equity market development in Latin America: Enhancing access to corporate finance</em>, OECD, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> This picture appeared to be changing. For example, private capital investment more than quadrupled between 2015 and 2022.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6903065e-134f-4d60-9604-056e6320cf52"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">67</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6903065e-134f-4d60-9604-056e6320cf52" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>LAVCA data on private capital activity in Latin America through year-end 2022</em>, LAVCA Venture Investors, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> But the future trajectory is less certain given tightening global economic conditions and changing investor risk appetites that appear to be curtailing the rise in investment.</p>
<p>Addressing low productivity growth will be essential to enabling the region to succeed, especially as its historical main driver of growththe demographic dividendtapers away. For emerging markets in other regions, outperformance has historically been enabled by factors such as domestic investment as well as openness to foreign capital inflows, integration with global export markets, and a business environment that fosters competition and the growth of large companies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bb36686c-e096-4d3c-b7cf-219054084094"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">68</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bb36686c-e096-4d3c-b7cf-219054084094" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/featured-insights/innovation-and-growth/outperformers-high-growth-emerging-economies-and-the-companies-that-propel-them">Outperformers: High-growth emerging economies and the companies that propel them</a></em>, McKinsey Global Institute, September 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> As Latin American economies navigate the current turmoil, finding approaches that can deliver productivity boosts and enable outperformance will be key.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 7</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20global%20institute/our%20research/what%20could%20a%20new%20era%20mean%20for%20latin%20america/svgz-latam-ex7.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="" src="/~/media/mckinsey/mckinsey%20global%20institute/our%20research/what%20could%20a%20new%20era%20mean%20for%20latin%20america/svgz-latam-ex7.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<h2>How can leaders in Latin America think about the road ahead?</h2>
<p>Responding to todays turbulence and major challengesincluding slowing economic growth, inflation, energy security, climate change, political tensions, and stress on social cohesionmay appear to be overwhelming, but there are grounds for optimism.</p>
<p>In the postwar period, despite intermittent periods of significant disruption, the world as a whole has been transformed. New majorities emerged. The share of the worlds population connected through their mobile phones and the internet soared above 50 percent. By 2019, 53 percent of the worlds population had income above the World Banks highest poverty line of $6.85 per day. The share of global GDP growth coming from low- and middle-income countries rose above 50 percent.</p>
<p>Latin America has been lifted by this wave but still operates well below its full potential both as a region and at the level of its constituent countries. It has remarkable intrinsic strengths: a population of more than 600 million with a high share of young adults, enormous reserves of minerals and abundant energy resources, and extensive biodiversity. However, the region has historically not always succeeded in harnessing its strengths. Its development has been restrained by a range of limiting factors, including lower levels of human capital, an underdeveloped financial sector, and a relative lack of infrastructure investment. Weaker public institutions and limitations in governance have contributed, too.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="00a66d7c-8366-4c7d-ba54-529c70bb4cc1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">69</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="00a66d7c-8366-4c7d-ba54-529c70bb4cc1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Government at a glance: Latin America and the Caribbean</em>, OECD, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> These issues are not new, but the prospect of a new era in the coming years makes their resolution all the more urgent. Can Latin America mobilize its strengthscollectively and within its individual economiesnot only to weather the current turbulence but to thrive in a new era as it unfolds? Can the region overcome its fragmentation in order to work toward common goalssetting integration goals, including structuring integrative infrastructure projects, and strengthening regional institutions?</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-left-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Latin America has remarkable intrinsic strengths: a population of more than 600 million with a high share of young adults, enormous reserves of minerals and abundant energy resources, and extensive biodiversity.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>The transition to a new era is a fork in the road for Latin America. If the transition is handled well, the regions abundance of critical resources for the net-zero transition could spur investment in infrastructure and human capital, and could catalyze both technology transfer and innovation. Shifting globalization could help Latin America become more connected: to financing, markets, and global corporations. Its population is young, supporting growth opportunities and new ways of doing things. A virtuous circle could emerge whereby investment and innovation raise productivity, boost private and public income, and build the capital stock, human and otherwise, to enable further growth. This could be the regions opportunity to experience the booming economic expansion seen in outperforming middle-income countries elsewhere. Conversely, if the transition is handled poorly, the region could find itself with rising inequality, increasing social tensions, and economic stagnation.</p>
<p>If the world is indeed in the early throes of a seismic shiftas the evidence appears to suggestwhat questions should Latin Americas leaders be asking themselves? They need both to prepare for the possibility of a new era and to position themselves to shape it.</p>
<hr>
<p>In <em>Memoirs</em>, the Chilean poet Pablo Neruda wrote, Latin America is very fond of the word hope. We like to be called the continent of hope.  This hope is really something like a promise of heaven, an IOU whose payment is always being put off. It is put off until the next legislative campaign, until next year, until the next century. We might borrow Nerudas metaphor and ask whether now is Latin Americas opportunity to translate its hope and promise into actionto cash out its IOU.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/andres-cadena">Andres Cadena</a></strong> is a senior partner in McKinseys Bogota office, <strong><a href="/our-people/olivia-white">Olivia White</a></strong> is an MGI director and a senior partner in the Bay Area office, and <strong>Camillo Lamanna</strong> is a consultant in the Sydney office.</p>
<hr>
<p>This article was edited by Janet Bush, an MGI executive editor in London.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div Card_content-block__pF6Z1"><span>Report</span><h6 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-6"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" economic potential of generative AI: The next productivity frontier</div></a></h6></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></main><div class="mck-u-sr-only" role="log" aria-live="polite"
