type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"What could a new era mean for Latin America","displayName":"What could a new era mean for Latin America","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"cf34bfb7-d90c-4e67-a387-d4ef7f16aa69","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":2,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"What could a new era mean for Latin America?"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"The new era of Latin American economies"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Current global challenges could usher in a new era. What might this mean for Latin American economies?"}},"sEODescription":{"value":"The world is facing a range of unprecedented challenges. We explore what these challenges might hold in store for emerging Latin American economies."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-07-20T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[audio 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003ch2\u003eAt a glance\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe current global upheaval may feel unprecedented, but there have been similar periods of acute disruption in recent history, each of which gave birth to a new era with its own distinctive landscape. The most recent era bore witness to the expansion of global value chains and the meteoric rise of digital technologies. Billions of people benefited from rapid growth and development, supported by macroeconomic stability.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eLatin America did not advance as much as it could have in the most recent era. It remained relatively peripheral to global economic integration, lagged behind in technological adoption, and did not establish itself at the frontier of innovation. And it experienced more muted growth, with some economies affected by the specters of debt and inflation.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eWhat could a new era look like for the world? The old unipolar world is giving way to a multipolar one with powerful new players. New technologies offer both promise and concern. The  new era has more elderly people, and perhaps more pangs of inequality. Countries are battling to reduce emissions, and access the resources needed to do so even while facing unprecedented debt and slowing growth.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIf a new era is dawning, how will Latin America fare? Can Latin America enhance its global participation in a multipolar world? Can it catch up with the curve of technological innovation and use technology to enhance equity? Can it benefit from its young population, address its entrenched inequalities, and define a new social contract to support long-term growth? Can it harness its natural resources to be an engine of the net-zero transition? Can it finally raise the bar on regional economic growth, investment, and productivity growth?\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMany unresolved questions remain, and pivotal choices are yet to be made as the region\u0026rsquo;s decision makers not only prepare for but seek to shape a new era.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn the past two and a half years,\u003c/strong\u003e extraordinary events have disrupted societies and businesses, and imposed significant challenges on the world economy. A recent McKinsey Global Institute (MGI) paper asked whether this cluster of significant events could presage a new era for the world and what that new era might look like. MGI drew on history and suggested a global framework based on a historical perspective to analyze the significance of current disruptions and gauge what may come next.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article considers what a global new era might mean for Latin America. Many of these world events have deeply affected the region. The pandemic hit Latin America hard, inflation has raised pressure on the continent\u0026rsquo;s low-income groups, and polarizing political tensions have been escalating. In Latin America, as in the rest of the world, these are volatile and uncertain times.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn its global research, MGI has identified clusters of disruptions in the relatively recent past. Three stand out: the immediate aftermath of World War II (1944\u0026ndash;46), the period around the oil crisis (1971\u0026ndash;73), and the breakup of the Soviet Union (1989\u0026ndash;92). Each changed the global landscape and ushered in a new era: the Postwar Boom (1944\u0026ndash;71), the Era of Contention (1971\u0026ndash;89), and the Era of Markets (1989\u0026ndash;2019). These prolonged periods bore witness to deep transformation in economies and societies\u0026mdash;the world with which we had grown familiar in 2019, before today\u0026rsquo;s turbulence, had been transformed in the 20 years since the previous bout of disruption, but the underlying terrain was relatively settled.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDuring the Era of Markets, there was a remarkable increase in global economic interconnectedness and rapid adoption of digital technologies. On both, Latin America fell behind. The region\u0026rsquo;s trade with the rest of the world increased, but at a slower pace than in countries at similar stages of their development. Latin America largely remained an exporter of primary goods. Many of its constituent economies had weak participation in global value chains. In the 2010s, many developing economies, most notably in East Asia, approached or even surpassed OECD average levels of digital adoption (as measured by mobile phone and fixed broadband subscription rates). In contrast, the gap between Latin America and OECD economies widened.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf the world is entering another era, how could Latin America fare? We look at the new era and its implications for the region through the lens of five domains: (1) world order: the institutions, frameworks, and rules that shape international affairs; (2) technology platforms: platforms and applied sciences enabling development and innovation; (3) demographic forces: demographic trends and socioeconomic contours across populations; (4) resource and energy systems: the systems for transporting and converting energy and materials for use; and (5) capitalization: drivers of global supply and demand, and trajectories of finance and wealth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis research uses Latin America as its lens, but, of course, Latin America is made up of a diverse mix of economies, peoples, and histories. Indeed, the ties between its constituent parts may not be as strong as the label might imply. Further, the very notion of Latin America may resonate more outside the region than within it. Nevertheless, this paper attempts to pull together questions and potential implications that may apply broadly across the region. We suggest that some common threads do exist, and that a region-wide set of open questions and choices remain to be made (Exhibit 1). The die is not yet cast.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003ch2\u003eWorld order\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Era of Markets witnessed the growth of a more globally integrated economy. The breakup of the Soviet Union left the United States as the unchallenged global political power. Global value chains spread rapidly when more economies opened up to the world\u0026rsquo;s trading system. China emerged as a global trading hub, becoming the world\u0026rsquo;s largest importer of primary goods\u0026mdash;particularly energy and minerals\u0026mdash;and the largest exporter of manufactured goods. How could the world order evolve? Globally, two directions of travel appear evident. First, a unipolar world centered on the United States could yield to multipolarity with the rise of China and emerging economies. Second, this multipolarity could lead to a realignment into more distinct regional blocs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWhat role can Latin America play in a multipolar world?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe region itself is embracing multipolarity. In 2000, the United States was the largest goods trading partner for almost all countries in Latin America. Between 2000 and 2021, Latin America\u0026rsquo;s trade with China grew 28-fold\u0026mdash;almost twice the rate of growth of trade with emerging-market and middle-income peers\u0026mdash;while the region maintained growing trade ties with the United States. In South America, China became the largest extraregional trade partner for almost all of the largest economies. In Central America, the United States remained the largest trade partner, but China rose to become the second largest. And between 2000 and 2021, Mexico witnessed both a 40-fold increase in trade with China and the largest increase in goods trade by value with the United States of any world economy except China.[[footnote 2]] Indeed, in 2019, Mexico overtook China as the largest US trading partner based on economic relationships bolstered by the US\u0026ndash;Canada\u0026ndash;Mexico Trade Agreement (Exhibit 2).[[footnote 3]] And the region\u0026rsquo;s multipolarity extends beyond trade. For example, in public opinion, surveys suggest that people view the United States and China equally favorably.[[footnote 4]] In global policy matters, as measured by voting practices at the UN General Assembly, Latin America is the region that is least firmly aligned to either the United States or China.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, Latin America has generally not leveraged its growing global interconnections to better integrate itself into the global economy. Excluding Mexico, primary goods represent about 56 percent of Latin America\u0026rsquo;s goods exports, and primary goods account for about 80 percent of the region\u0026rsquo;s goods exports to China. In emerging-market and middle-income peers, both figures are closer to 30 percent.[[footnote 6]] With the war in Ukraine raising the prominence of geopolitics in trading partnerships, Latin America\u0026rsquo;s economies could benefit from the shifting political landscape as economies seek to diversify. Focusing more narrowly on trade with North America, \u0026ldquo;nearshoring\u0026rdquo; to Latin America could deliver significant economic opportunities.[[footnote 7]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWill Latin America\u0026rsquo;s countries strengthen their interconnections to further their common economic goals?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLatin America is home to more than 600 million people, and it is unusual in that the vast majority of them (about 95 percent) have at least one of two official languages: Spanish or Portuguese.[[footnote 8]] In comparison, other regions have many languages that can create barriers to interconnectedness.[[footnote 9]] Yet by some measures, Latin America\u0026rsquo;s constituent countries enjoy weaker cohesion than those in other regions. The quality of intraregional road transportation links is the lowest of any region other than sub-Saharan Africa.[[footnote 10]] Intraregional exports in Latin America account for 14 percent of total exports, a significantly lower proportion than most other regions, and commitments to building regional trade integration have not always delivered in their implementation.[[footnote 11]] In Europe, the majority of students who study abroad do so in another European country despite the barriers imposed by the continent\u0026rsquo;s many languages. In Latin America, most study-abroad students travel outside the region.[[footnote 12]] In a more multipolar world, Latin America may have greater opportunities if it can build connections despite the specific challenges of its topology.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003ch2\u003eTechnology platforms\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDuring the Era of Markets, the World Wide Web and a plunge in the cost of processing drove a digital revolution. From nearly zero at the start of the era, by 2019 the proportion of the world\u0026rsquo;s population that had a mobile phone was 67 percent, and 54 percent used the internet.[[footnote 13]] Almost 99 percent of data had been stored on analog media; almost all data are now stored digitally. Renewed momentum may come from new and emerging technologies, such as applied AI. Geopolitics may influence the technological sphere as more fractured geopolitics make strategic autonomy a greater priority.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWill Latin America accelerate equitable access to technology and building the tech skills it needs for today\u0026rsquo;s digital world?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the 2010s, the number of internet users in Latin America doubled to about two-thirds of the population. But by some measures, the region fell behind. In the 2010s, developing economies in East Asia, for example, closed the gap with OECD peers in fixed broadband subscription rates and overtook the OECD average for mobile subscription rates. However, in Latin America, the gap with the OECD average widened on both measures.[[footnote 14]] Moreover, there are substantial differences in access and use across countries, income quintiles, and the rural-urban divide. For example, while internet use in Uruguay is close to the OECD average, in El Salvador it is almost 40 percentage points lower. Another\u0026nbsp;striking example is Peru, where about 75 percent of top-quintile earners are regular internet users, versus 15 percent in the bottom quintile; this 60-percentage-point gap is four times the average in OECD economies. The increasingly digital world risks entrenching inequalities, particularly given skills shortages. Less than half of Latin Americans have sufficient skills to use computers for basic professional tasks, which likely undermines the productivity of firms, particularly small ones.[[footnote 15]] The region has a clear imperative to address education and skills development.[[footnote 16]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eCan Latin America catch up with the global technology curve?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLatin America has often been a latecomer to technologies. Mechanized farming is one prosaic example. Adoption of tractors in the region is about one-fifth of that in East Asia and Southeast Asia, although the technology has existed for more than two centuries.[[footnote 17]] In the case of digital technology, while mobile money adoption soared in Africa in the 2010s, Latin America\u0026rsquo;s adoption reached only 2 percent by 2019, about eight times lower than the rate in Africa.[[footnote 18]] However, the pandemic triggered a boom in the adoption of technology, including digital payments and e-commerce. In Brazil, for instance, over half the population joined the Pix digital payment system in less than a year.[[footnote 19]] Technology adoption has been supported by the rise of new, innovative firms: four-fifths of Latin America\u0026rsquo;s start-up \u0026ldquo;unicorns\u0026rdquo; focus on fintech and e-commerce.[[footnote 20]] This rapid rise in technology adoption is remarkable, and it demonstrates the potential to scale existing technologies more rapidly than in regions with more established value chains. However, whether Latin America can establish itself as a leader in cutting-edge technologies is less clear. At about 0.6 percent of GDP, regional investment in research and development is less than one-quarter of the average in the OECD and China. The region accounts for less than 2 percent of the world\u0026rsquo;s patent applications; of these, less than one-fifth are filed by Latin Americans.[[footnote 21]] Latin America imports about eight times more intellectual property than it exports, the highest ratio of any region outside Africa (Exhibit 3).[[footnote 22]] As frontier technologies such as AI take off, the region risks lagging behind once again. For example, estimates suggest that AI\u0026rsquo;s impact on Latin America\u0026rsquo;s economy will be three to five times lower than in North America and China.[[footnote 23]] Latin America\u0026rsquo;s future will depend on its ability both to continue to integrate existing technologies and to find pockets of opportunity to drive the frontier.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003ch2\u003eDemographic forces\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSweeping urbanization, decreasing fertility rates, aging, rising educational access, and falling poverty marked the Era of Markets. But imbalances remained. Wealth and income inequality within countries rose across the world. In the next era, many economies are likely to experience stagnant or even shrinking pools of working-age people and a rapid rise in the share of older people in overall populations. Within-country inequality has risen to its highest level since its peak at the beginning of the 20th century, and in the new era, social cohesion may be under ever-increasing pressure.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eCan Latin America find a new growth model before its demographics catch up?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn estimated 75 percent of Latin America\u0026rsquo;s GDP growth in 2000\u0026ndash;19 was due to people entering the workforce, and only 25 percent attributable to productivity gains. For comparison, in China, more than 95 percent of growth during the same period was due to productivity gains.[[footnote 24]] This labor-led growth model is complemented by Latin America\u0026rsquo;s young working-age population\u0026mdash;about one-quarter of its population is aged between 15 and 30, the second-highest share of young adults, behind Africa. The region\u0026rsquo;s relative youth is particularly marked in many Central American countries.[[footnote 25]] It may deliver a suite of benefits, particularly because young Latin Americans are among the most entrepreneurial globally.[[footnote 26]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut Latin America\u0026rsquo;s ability to rely on workforce expansion to drive growth will not last much longer. The region is aging fast as birth rates fall and life expectancy rises (Exhibit 4).[[footnote 27]] In the next 30 years, the absolute number of people aged over 60 in Latin America will more than double to near 200 million or over 25 percent of the population, placing increasing pressure on pension, healthcare, and social-support systems.[[footnote 28]] The working-age share of the population in large Latin American economies such as Brazil, Chile, and Colombia has already peaked and is now falling, while Mexico and most of Central America could reach this tipping point within a decade.[[footnote 29]] Without a shift to a new growth paradigm, such as one spurred by investment and innovation, Latin America\u0026rsquo;s changing demographics could herald a regional slowdown.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWill Latin America tackle entrenched inequalities and define a new social contract for growth?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInequality is a deeply rooted challenge in the region.[[footnote 30]] Sixteen of the 30 most unequal countries in the world (measured by income distribution) are in Latin America.[[footnote 31]] But inequality extends beyond income. For example, women\u0026rsquo;s labor-force participation is about 25 percentage points lower than men\u0026rsquo;s.[[footnote 32]] Almost one-quarter of rural inhabitants do not have access to piped water, compared with less than 5 percent without access in urban areas.[[footnote 33]] And intergenerational mobility is low, propagating inequalities through generations. In Brazil and Colombia, it could take about ten generations for a low-income family to achieve an average income, compared with between four and five generations, on average, in OECD economies.[[footnote 34]] In addition, about 50 percent of the region\u0026rsquo;s labor is informal, and about 25 percent of urban dwellers live in informal settlements.[[footnote 35]] Persistent inequality and a perceived lack of opportunity have likely contributed to growing unrest. Indeed, the prospect of tightening economic conditions and relatively weak governance in the region suggest that some economies may be vulnerable to falling into state fragility.[[footnote 36]] Consider that between 2010 and 2021, Latin America witnessed the largest relative decline of any world region in indexes of government effectiveness, rule of law, and control of corruption.[[footnote 37]] Fragility can often be exacerbated by natural resource wealth.[[footnote 38]] Several of the largest economies in the region are grappling with social reforms relating to health, social security, and labor. Whether a new social contract can emerge, delivering high-quality employment and opportunity to the region\u0026rsquo;s citizens, is unclear.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003ch2\u003eResource and energy systems\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDuring the Era of Markets, global consumption of increasingly abundant fossil fuels continued to rise, but this broader access to energy resources came with rising awareness of the damage being done to the climate. Many countries have committed to striving to achieve net-zero carbon emissions, and attention has shifted from investment in fossil fuels to investment in replacing them. However, in the new era, countries may well need to grapple with a paradox: the current pace of investment in renewable energy is too slow to meet ambitions for carbon abatement, but investment in fossil fuels may be too low to make up the shortfall in energy supply. By 2019, 72 percent of net new annual electricity-generating capacity globally came from renewables.[[footnote 39]] However, 84 percent of the global gigajoules consumed still came from fossil energy sources\u0026mdash;a figure that has been broadly stable for 30 years.[[footnote 40]] Global investment in energy supply had stagnated; in 2022, global spending on energy supply infrastructure was well below the 2014 peak. Achieving net zero will require a significant ramp-up in global energy investment, but the war in Ukraine and tightening global financial conditions could challenge the velocity of the transition.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHow will Latin America power itself and reduce its greenhouse-gas emissions?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLatin America faces three idiosyncrasies that may shape its path to decarbonization. First, many economies in the region rely on fossil fuels for income and foreign exchange.[[footnote 41]] At the same time, the region enjoys some of the best conditions globally for renewable power generation, including hydro, wind, and solar power; the Andes have the highest photovoltaic power potential of any region in the world.[[footnote 42]] In the near term, higher energy commodity prices may encourage fossil fuel exports and add momentum for the domestic shift to renewables. Between 2018 and 2022, Latin America\u0026rsquo;s solar power capacity grew by around 35 percent every year. This was well over double the global average growth rate, and the fastest of any world region.[[footnote 43]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, even though electricity production is relatively decarbonized by global standards, electrifying and decarbonizing energy as a whole is still a formidable task that will require significant shifts and investment. About 60 percent of electricity in Latin America is from renewable sources\u0026mdash;twice the global average.[[footnote 44]] But only about 20 percent of final energy use in Latin America is from electricity, a figure similar to the global average.[[footnote 45]] Decarbonization of sectors such as transportation and industry could be accelerated by making further use of the region\u0026rsquo;s potential for solar, wind, biomethane, and biofuels as well as existing hydroelectric power.[[footnote 46]] Latin America could also become a significant low-cost producer of hydrogen, not only supporting domestic decarbonization but also potentially supplying a growing global market.[[footnote 47]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThird, Latin America will need to address land-use emissions more than most other regions. Energy accounts for only 43 percent of greenhouse-gas emissions in Latin America, versus a global average of about 74 percent. Agriculture, land-use change, and forestry contribute 45 percent of its emissions, versus a global average of about 14 percent.[[footnote 48]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDecarbonization will create domestic trade-offs. McKinsey research found that the region would have to allocate just under 10 percent of its GDP on physical assets to supporting the net-zero transition, about two percentage points above the world average.[[footnote 49]] Delivering on domestic decarbonization will require overcoming challenges such as securing financing and unlocking permitting and approvals, and addressing talent and infrastructure gaps.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eCan Latin America be an engine of the global net-zero transition?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e Many critical resources needed for the net-zero transition are abundant in the region (Exhibit 5). Latin America holds about half of the world\u0026rsquo;s lithium, 36 percent of its copper, and 16 percent of its nickel. Brazil is estimated to have one of the largest reserves of rare earths outside China.[[footnote 50]] Moreover, Latin America also contains about 50 percent of the world\u0026rsquo;s biodiversity and 23 percent of its forests\u0026mdash;key elements of global climate stability and broader sustainability, and a crucial complement to the energy transition.[[footnote 51]] The region therefore has a unique opportunity to support global decarbonization, from renewable value chains to forest carbon sequestration. However, there are potential tensions between the needs of local communities and the global requirements of the transition. The debate over lithium mining in Chile is an example.[[footnote 52]] Similarly, reducing deforestation and practicing afforestation would need to be carefully managed in order to ensure that forest-border communities benefit.[[footnote 53]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003ch2\u003eCapitalization\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs its name suggests, the Era of Markets saw the rise of market economies around the world. Hypergrowth in China\u0026mdash;at close to 10 percent annually throughout the era\u0026mdash;as well as growth in India and some Southeast Asian economies propelled a shift in global GDP growth from high-income to low- and middle-income economies. In advanced economies, the productivity boom of the late 1990s started tapering off in the mid-2000s.[[footnote 54]] But the Era of Markets also witnessed a record rise in household, nonfinancial corporate, and government debt. Total debt in advanced economies is at its highest level since the end of World War II.[[footnote 55]] In a new era, whose start is marked by a spike in inflation and rising interest rates, the global balance sheet seems exposed. Accelerating productivity growth will be badly needed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHow will the region navigate global economic headwinds?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe region appears to be recovering from the pandemic-induced shock. Consumption, employment, and economic activity are all above prepandemic levels.[[footnote 56]] But inflation remains high despite the fact that the region\u0026rsquo;s central banks moved faster and more aggressively than most advanced economies in raising rates.[[footnote 57]] Public debt jumped to over 70 percent of GDP during the pandemic, which could prove to be a drag on future growth and raise questions about debt sustainability if economic conditions were to deteriorate (Exhibit 6).[[footnote 58]] Ongoing US monetary tightening could have a negative impact on Latin America\u0026rsquo;s economies. Slower global growth could remove the recent counterbalancing effect of higher commodity prices.[[footnote 59]] Given that Latin American governments and corporations have a high proportion of debt denominated in US dollars relative to others, the region\u0026rsquo;s ability to service its debt is particularly exposed to exchange-rate risk.[[footnote 60]] This risk is exacerbated as the US dollar continues to appreciate relative to many local currencies.[[footnote 61]]\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 6]]\n\u003ch4\u003eWill Latin America be able to drive productivity growth?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSince the early 1980s, Latin America\u0026rsquo;s productivity growth rate has averaged only 0.4 percent each year\u0026mdash;about one-fifth of the average in developing economies globally.[[footnote 62]] While comparable emerging Asian and Eastern European economies have experienced rapid real per capita economic growth, Latin America has not (Exhibit 7).[[footnote 63]] There are wide-ranging reasons for this, including higher barriers to doing business as well as gaps in human, technological, and infrastructural capital.[[footnote 64]] The competitive dynamics of the region contribute, too. Firms are polarized into large incumbents and a long tail of small, unproductive, and often informal firms, with a \u0026ldquo;missing middle\u0026rdquo; of dynamic midsize companies that can challenge incumbents, innovate, and drive growth.[[footnote 65]] In particular, midsize firms face challenges accessing capital to enable growth; about 30 percent of them report finance as a major constraint.[[footnote 66]] This picture appeared to be changing. For example, private capital investment more than quadrupled between 2015 and 2022.[[footnote 67]] But the future trajectory is less certain given tightening global economic conditions and changing investor risk appetites that appear to be curtailing the rise in investment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAddressing low productivity growth will be essential to enabling the region to succeed, especially as its historical main driver of growth\u0026mdash;the demographic dividend\u0026mdash;tapers away. For emerging markets in other regions, outperformance has historically been enabled by factors such as domestic investment as well as openness to foreign capital inflows, integration with global export markets, and a business environment that fosters competition and the growth of large companies.[[footnote 68]] As Latin American economies navigate the current turmoil, finding approaches that can deliver productivity boosts and enable outperformance will be key.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 7]]\n\u003ch2\u003eHow can leaders in Latin America think about the road ahead?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eResponding to today\u0026rsquo;s turbulence and major challenges\u0026mdash;including slowing economic growth, inflation, energy security, climate change, political tensions, and stress on social cohesion\u0026mdash;may appear to be overwhelming, but there are grounds for optimism.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the postwar period, despite intermittent periods of significant disruption, the world as a whole has been transformed. New majorities emerged. The share of the world\u0026rsquo;s population connected through their mobile phones and the internet soared above 50 percent. By 2019, 53 percent of the world\u0026rsquo;s population had income above the World Bank\u0026rsquo;s highest poverty line of $6.85 per day. The share of global GDP growth coming from low- and middle-income countries rose above 50 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLatin America has been lifted by this wave but still operates well below its full potential both as a region and at the level of its constituent countries. It has remarkable intrinsic strengths: a population of more than 600 million with a high share of young adults, enormous reserves of minerals and abundant energy resources, and extensive biodiversity. However, the region has historically not always succeeded in harnessing its strengths. Its development has been restrained by a range of limiting factors, including lower levels of human capital, an underdeveloped financial sector, and a relative lack of infrastructure investment. Weaker public institutions and limitations in governance have contributed, too.[[footnote 69]] These issues are not new, but the prospect of a new era in the coming years makes their resolution all the more urgent. Can Latin America mobilize its strengths\u0026mdash;collectively and within its individual economies\u0026mdash;not only to weather the current turbulence but to thrive in a new era as it unfolds? Can the region overcome its fragmentation in order to work toward common goals\u0026mdash;setting integration goals, including structuring integrative infrastructure projects, and strengthening regional institutions?\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe transition to a new era is a fork in the road for Latin America. If the transition is handled well, the region\u0026rsquo;s abundance of critical resources for the net-zero transition could spur investment in infrastructure and human capital, and could catalyze both technology transfer and innovation. Shifting globalization could help Latin America become more connected: to financing, markets, and global corporations. Its population is young, supporting growth opportunities and new ways of doing things. A virtuous circle could emerge whereby investment and innovation raise productivity, boost private and public income, and build the capital stock, human and otherwise, to enable further growth. This could be the region\u0026rsquo;s opportunity to experience the booming economic expansion seen in outperforming middle-income countries elsewhere. Conversely, if the transition is handled poorly, the region could find itself with rising inequality, increasing social tensions, and economic stagnation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf the world is indeed in the early throes of a seismic shift\u0026mdash;as the evidence appears to suggest\u0026mdash;what questions should Latin America\u0026rsquo;s leaders be asking themselves? They need both to prepare for the possibility of a new era and to position themselves to shape it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn \u003cem\u003eMemoirs\u003c/em\u003e, the Chilean poet Pablo Neruda wrote, \u0026ldquo;Latin America is very fond of the word \u0026lsquo;hope.\u0026rsquo; We like to be called the \u0026lsquo;continent of hope.\u0026rsquo; \u0026hellip; This hope is really something like a promise of heaven, an IOU whose payment is always being put off. It is put off until the next legislative campaign, until next year, until the next century.\u0026rdquo; We might borrow Neruda\u0026rsquo;s metaphor and ask whether now is Latin America\u0026rsquo;s opportunity to translate its hope and promise into action\u0026mdash;to cash out its IOU.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":{"name":"MGI Research","displayName":"MGI Research","title":{"value":"MGI Research"},"relatedlinks":{"url":"/mgi/overview"},"landinglinks":{"jsonValue":{"value":[]}}}},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-07-20T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/on-the-cusp-of-a-new-era\"\u003eOn the cusp of a new era?\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; This publication does not specify the metric of biodiversity used.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eJohn Bartlett, \u0026ldquo;Mining of lithium, key to the climate fight, faces new scrutiny in Chile,\u0026rdquo; \u003cem\u003eNew York Times\u003c/em\u003e, January 6, 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/the-net-zero-transition-what-it-would-cost-what-it-could-bring\"\u003eThe net-zero transition: What it would cost, what it could bring\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; McKinsey Global Institute, January 2022.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eSee, for example, \u003cem\u003eThe productivity puzzle\u003c/em\u003e, McKinsey Global Institute, March 2017.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eIn G-20 countries, the ratio of total debt to GDP is over 300 percent. From 2000 to 2021, the world created $2 in new debt for each $1 in net new investment. Asset prices soared, supporting an accumulation of \u0026ldquo;paper wealth.\u0026rdquo; Net worth grew by 170 percentage points relative to GDP, yet three-quarters of wealth growth stemmed from asset price inflation rather than saving and investing.
